awd_titl_txt: Diophantine Analysis: From Structured to Random
awd_abstract_narration:
The award is concerned with the tension between the random versus deterministic properties of integer and real solutions to certain equations as well as for the illusive parity of the number of prime factors of an integer. These features in special cases have applications to the design of efficient circuits and algorithms. In terms of practical applications of the project, the PI expects that the design of optimally efficient universal quantum gates using the richness of solutions to Diophantine equations associated with arithmetic groups will be used if a physical quantum computer is built.

Understanding solutions of algebraic equations in integers is a central theme in the theory of numbers. The focus of this project is on equations which have many such solutions. The only general method known to produce solutions is the Hardy-Littlewood "circle method" which applies when there are many variables and the solutions are very abundant. This project is concerned with the study of the richness of solutions to such equations over the integers and the reals, when there are few variables and especially in the critical dimension. Among the new tools to be employed to make progress are, the dynamics affine polynomial morphism groups, the method of auxiliary polynomials from transcendence and the theory of random Gaussian Fields. A theme that is captured in the study of these and related problems, is determinism versus randomness and it allows one in certain special cases to design various optimally efficient universal quantum gates. Another direction to be pursued with this theme is the theoretical and computational study of the parity in the number of prime factors of a number.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
Most of the goals of the original proposal for this grant were achieved. Some of the problems remain open and there were a number of unexpected developments and applications leading to new vistas. The relevant publications described in this summary are listed in the products section of the final report. What follows is a brief account of the main achievements.

    The question of the universal distribution of topologies of the connected components a random high degree real algebraic hypersurface in projective n-space as well as that of nodal sets of random monochromatic waves was determined in joint works with Igor Wigman and Yaiza Canzani. Numerical Monte Carlo simulations by Alex Barnett and collaborators yielded these distributions for n=2 but not for n at least 3. This was eventually explained by my conjecture which has been partly proved by Hugo Copin and collaborators that the percolation threshold for the Gaussian fields associated to these random hypersurfaces is positive for n>2. Correspondingly the zero set is supercritical and has a giant component rendering the many connected components invisible in any feasible 3 dimensional (and higher) numerical simulation.

    In the study of diophantine geometry of integer points on log K_3's we (Bourgain-Gamburd-Sarnak and Ghosh-Sarnak) a theory was developed at least for the Markoff such surfaces.For these the nonlinear Vieta morphism group is a key tool in developing aspects of the theory. The main connectivity conjecture connected of the corresponding mod q reductions (strong approximation) posed and studied in the B-G-S series is now mostly proved. The last and important step is due to William Chen who interpreting the connectivity conjecture in terms of the connected components of the moduli space of elliptic curves with G-structures where G is SL(2,F_p), used algebraic geometric arguments to establish divisibility properties of the orbit sizes which are enough to complete the program. In another direction in G-S the local to global principle for finding integral points on these surfaces are studied. It is shown that almost all such surfaces (ie representations by the Markoff type cubic) satisfy a local to global principle "Hasse Principle". On the other hand there are infinitely many  Hasse failures  coming from both reciprocity obstructions (Integral Brauer Manin type Colliot-Thelen et al) as well as many other failures that are more mysterious. In Ghosh-Meiri and Sarnak this theory of Markoff cubics is used to study and answer questions of commutators in group theory. Specifically, Shalev's question of whether there is a profinite local to global to principal for commutators in S-arithmetic groups is shown to be no. The reciprocity obstructions from Markoff's equation are used to build such examples. The notoriously difficult log K_3's namely which numbers are sums of three cubes, enjoyed some conditional progress in the PHD of Victor Wang supported by this grant. He showed that almost all numbers which do not give remainders 4 or 5 when divided by 9 are sums of three cubes,
if one assumes a series of standard conjectures concerning L -functions.

     Motivated by applied problems of implementing  microwave coplanar wave guides Alicia Kollar and Sarnak study the problem of prescibing the Adjacency spectrum of large finite cubic graphs. The optimal gap at the top, that is at 3, corresponds to optimal expanders namely Ramanujan Graphs of great interest in combinatorics. The gap at the bottom -3 is critical in the waveguide problem and the gap in the middle is of interest for the stability of carbon clusters in chemistry. We idenitify maximal gap intervals and gap sets via various techniques ranging from arithmetic ones to special abelian covers connected to Bloch wave theory. Of special interest are the rigidity properties that set in on restricting to planar such graphs and ones which are convex in the sense of Thurston as well as Fullerenes. For these in joint work Kollar-Fan Wei and Sarnak it is shown thatt there is a unique maximal gap set which we identify explicitly.

   In Kurasov-Sarnak an in depth study of the additive and trancendence structure of the spectrum of metric graphs is carried out. Metric graphs have been studied by physicists, chemists and mathematicians over the years. Using some diophantine geomettry (specifically the proof of the Lang G_m Conjecture  by M. Laurent) as one of the inputs we are able to undrestand the linear structure over Q of the spectra of these metric graphs. Applying the trace formula for such graphs leads to exotic crystalline measures which allow one to answer questions of Yves Meyer and Jefferey Lagarias and others about the existence of such measures.
